description:
Salvia hispanica, commonly known as chia, is a species of flowering plant in the mint family Lamiaceae. It is an annual herbaceous plant native to central and southern Mexico and Guatemala.

Salvia hispanica is grown for its edible seeds, which are rich in omega-3 fatty acids, protein, fiber, and various vitamins and minerals. The seeds can be consumed whole, ground into a powder, or used to make various food products.

The plant grows up to 1 meter tall and produces small, purple or white flowers. The leaves are green, lance-shaped, and covered in fine hairs. The seeds are small, oval-shaped, and range in color from black to white.

Chia seeds have a long history of use as a food and medicinal crop in Mesoamerican cultures. In recent years, they have gained popularity worldwide as a superfood due to their impressive nutritional profile and potential health benefits, including their role in supporting cardiovascular health and weight management.
